Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story: I was sweeping up dust near the scaffolding when I spotted the spill—a slick, oily patch right in the middle of the walkway. My supervisor always says, “Safety first, no exceptions.” I knew I had to clean it up before someone got hurt. As I reached for the mop, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from Miriam, a young woman from my congregation. She and her fiancé wanted to know if I could officiate their wedding next summer. They were anxious to set the date, and I knew how important it was for them to have their rabbi’s blessing. I could picture their hopeful faces, waiting for my reply. But the foreman was already eyeing me, expecting me to keep the site safe and tidy. My hands trembled as I weighed the urgency of the spill against the couple’s need for reassurance. I felt torn, caught between the demands of my work boots and my rabbinic calling, unsure which responsibility should come first.
